Join the extremities of these to obtain, with the first three sides, the figure described ABCDA. Measure the area of this figure by means of a planimeter; in this case the area was found to be 423 sq. ins.

Now the area of the figure =  A =  \int_0^{\pi/2} r^2 \, d\theta, or 2 \times \frac{1}{2} \int_0^{\pi/2} |C| \, d|C|, so that if we divide the area by the range in r, the mean value of the squares is determined.
In this case the range of r = 16 \times 4^2 = 135.5 for 4 units, and thus 1 sq. in. = 16 sq. units.

blocks.text: The rule for the area of a figure, viz., \int_A r^2 \, d|r|, may be usefully employed to find the height of the centroid of an area above a certain base.
